Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: An Interdisciplinary Study of Hyperdiverse Endophytic Fungi and Their Function in Boreal Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
As major sources of ecological and evolutionary innovation, symbioses drive genome evolution, ecological diversification, and speciation - and thus shape all dimensions of the diversity of life. The goal of this study is to examine the taxonomic, genetic, and functional diversity of endophytes, one of Earth's most prevalent, but least-understood, groups of symbionts. Endophytic fungi are found within healthy above-ground tissues of all plants (and in lichens as "endolichenic fungi"), including crop- and forage plants, and peak in their phylogenetic diversity in boreal forests, an imperiled ecosystem of immense global importance. This interdisciplinary study will develop a novel biodiversity informatics pipeline to discover, evaluate, and describe new species of boreal endophytes at multiple spatial and phylogenetic scales around the circumboreal belt. Culture-based and culture-free surveys will yield the largest sample of endophytic fungi to date, setting the stage for testing novel hypotheses regarding the evolution of ecological modes in the Ascomycota, the most species-rich fungal phylum; developing new model systems for evaluating, for the first time, the functional diversity of endophyte communities; and elucidating the genetic mechanisms shaping that diversity, including mobile genetic elements, endohyphal microbial symbionts, and genome evolution. Data will be managed and released through an integrated system built around the Suite of Nucleotide Analysis Programs (SNAP) and made public through a dedicated web portal, EnDoBiodiversity.org.

This highly integrative project also seeks to promote diversity in science for high school students, STEM teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars at scales ranging from local outreach at four universities to widespread international collaboration. Hosting of international researchers, leadership of international workshops, and development of international symposia will synergize fungal taxonomy and molecular systematics while boosting rates of species descriptions to a level never reached before and fostering novel collaborations in the study of fungal symbionts. Building and sharing of novel biodiversity informatics tools will be complemented by development and deposition of permanent fungal culture collections and extensive molecular sequence datasets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This interdisciplinary project examined the taxonomic, genetic, and functional diversity of endophytic fungi (endophytes) in boreal forests. The objectives were to (1) determine the scope and distribution of endophyte diversity with regard to hosts, geography, and ecologically relevant environmental factors; (2) assess functional diversity and mechanisms underlying genetic diversity of endophytes; and (3) develop transformative taxonomic tools for cataloguing and describing new species of endophytes. As this project was a collaborative effort, our specific focus was to develop novel biodiversity informatics pipelines and visualization tools to discover, evaluate, and describe new fungal taxa at multiple spatial and phylogenetic scales.

Three web portals were developed through this project. (1) The Mobyle SNAP Workbench portal includes a comprehensive suite of tools for population genetic and genomic analyses, metagenomics, clustering and principal components, as well as several methods for phylogenetic inference. Computationally intensive methods to handle next generation sequence data are being implemented in workflows that leverage NSF's XSEDE resources. These include workflows for genome mapping, assembly and annotation, comparative genomics, and genotype-by-sequencing. Two other web portals are part of the Tree-Based Alignment Selector (T-BAS) toolkit: (2) T-BAS v1.0 (available online) integrates phylogenetic and taxonomic information, DNA sequence alignments, and ecological metadata, and performs BLAST and phylogenetic placement of unknown reads in the context of a predetermined reference tree (currently for the Pezizomycotina). (3) T-BAS v2.0 (in prototype) will integrate any user-specified reference tree, associated metadata, and population genomic variants, expanding the scope of the tool beyond the Pezizomycotina alone. We developed and maintain a project website, which includes links to the SNAP/T-BAS portals and other project resources.

This project supported the training of two Ph.D. students and two Master’s students, two undergraduates in computer science, two IT technicians, and one postdoc (shared with Duke University). Annual summer workshops were organized through NCSU’s Creating Awareness of Agriculture & Life Sciences Disciplines, Degree Programs and Discoveries program, and hosted high school students from the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics and students referred from the NC Society of Hispanic Professionals and other community partners. These workshops introduced students to next generation sequencing linked to guided-inquiry computer exercises for visualizing and exploring DNA sequence variation. Online tutorials are being developed and will be distributed as public toolkits for curriculum development.
